name: Lazarus Group TTPs
description: TTPs identified in Lazarus Group's Operation Blacksmith

techniques.comment: The group Lazarus uses HazyLoad, a custom-made proxy tool. This helps establish direct access to the infected system without having to repeatedly exploit CVE-2021-44228.
The attackers create an additional user account on the system, granting it administrative privileges.
The attackers downloaded and used credential dumping utilities such as ProcDump and MimiKatz, which resulted in unauthorized credential access.

The campaign used remote access trojans (RATs) where one of them used as a medium of command and control (C2) communications. They tracked this Telegram-based RAT as “NineRAT”. It was written in DLang and showed a definitive shift in the Lazarus Group's tactics.
The attackers exploited CVE-2021-44228, also known as Log4Shell, on publicly facing VMWare Horizon servers as an initial access means to vulnerable public-facing servers.
NineRAT uses Telegram as its C2 channel for accepting commands and communicating their outputs. The use of this service aids in evading network detection.
Some activities targeted specific ports. This is likely to avoid raising suspicion.
The malware interacts with the local system to collect data and exfiltrate it.
Tools were transferred into the compromised environment to effect exploitation.
Attackers modified the registry as part of their process.
Observed commands indicate the attackers were manually identifying files and directories of interest on the compromised systems.
The attackers ran commands to enumerate network configuration data.
The attackers stopped certain processes, likely as a means of evasion.
The delivery of an executable file onto a system ran successfully.
The attackers ran commands to identify software installed on the system.
The attackers ran several commands to enumerate information about the device hardware in order to determine the capabilities of the system.
Lazarus Group was able to exploit a vulnerability to elevate privileges.
The attackers added new Windows accounts to maintain persistence within the environment.
BottomLoader can create persistence for newer versions or completely new follow-up payloads by creating a “.URL” file in the Startup directory to run the PowerShell command to download the payload.
The attackers checked for specific software installed on the system.
This technique was used by the attackers to view activities on the system.
The Lazarus Group used PowerShell commands to download and execute payloads.
The malware used binary padding to encode its data.
The malware has a built-in capability to disable or modify security tools.
NineRAT interacts with the Telegram channel using DLang-based libraries implemented to talk to Telegram’s APIs. This allows the malware to execute various commands through API interaction.
Lazarus was successful in exploiting a vulnerability in a remote service to gain access.
Lazarus Group transferred tools into the compromised environment to facilitate their activities.
